title: Fundamentals of E-Commerce Technologies
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: An overview of the principles of E-Commerce. The origin and growth of E-Commerce. Technologies that support the development of E-Commerce applications. Business models and strategies for E-Commerce. Legal issues related to E-Commerce such as privacy, consumer rights and intellectual property. Information interchange and application sharing via extensible markup languages and web services to support logistics and operations management.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have understandings of the fundamentals and background information about E-Commerce Technologies.
recommended_readings: Kenneth C. Laudon & Carol Guercio Traver, E-commerce 2015: business, technology, society, 11th Edition, Global Edition, Pearson, 2015 (LT) David D. VanHoose, E-Commerce Economics, 2nd edition, Routledge, 2011 (DV) (e-book available through the library’s webpage). Danny Goodman, Dynamic HTML: the definitive reference, O’Reilly, 2002 Dick Oliver & Michael Morrison, Sams teach yourself HTML and CSS in 24 hours, Sams, 2006 Shelley Powers, Learning Javascript, O’Reilly, 2007 Luke Welling and Laura Thomson, PHP and MySQL web development, Addison-Wesley, 2009

title: Electronic Payments Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: This course covers various methods of transferring payments over the Internet andcompares their functionality. Topics include electronic money, electronic contracts, micro-payments, authenticity, integrity and reliability of transactions, encryption and digital signature techniques needed to support electronic cash, and technologies available to support secure transactions on the Internet.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should understand the characteristics of payment systems; the motivation of electronic payment; major electronic payment business models; electronic payment system infrastructure and related security issues; major electronic payment systems; various cryptographic techniques that are used by electronic payment systems; and relevant legal issues.
required_readings: M. H. Sharif, Protocols for Secure Electronic Commerce, 2nd Edition, CRC
recommended_readings: Weidong Kou, Payment Technologies for E-Commerce, 1st Edition, Springer. Donal O’Mahony, Michael Peirce, Hitesh Tewari, Electronic Payment Systems for E-Commerce, 2nd Edition, Artech House. Kornel Terplan, Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment, 1st Edition, CRC.

title: Logistics Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: The integrated logistics management concept. Customer service. Channels of distribution. Order processing. Transportation systems. Storage and material handling systems. Inventory management. Information systems for order processing and inventory tracking. Impact of Internet and electronic data intercharge (EDI) on order cycles, vendor-customer communications and inventory. Global logistics. Third-party logistics.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have developed an appreciation of the practical significance and complexities of logistics management, gained an understanding of the key processes involved, and mastered some analytical tools useful in the designing, operating and improving of a logistics system.
required_readings: Ghiani, G., G. Laporte and R. Musmanno, Introduction to Logistics Systems Management, 2013, Wiley.
recommended_readings: Ballou, R.H., Business Logistics Management/Supply Chain Management, 5th edition, 2004, Prentice-Hall. Christopher, M., Logistics and Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2011, Financial Times/ Prentice-Hall. Chopra, S. and P. Meindl, Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2010, Prentice-Hall.  Powell and Baker, Management Science: the art of modeling with spreadsheets (2nd Edition), 2009, Wiley.

title: Cryptography, Information Security and E-Commerce
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Symmetric cryptography. Asymmetric cryptography including integer factorization, discrete logarithm and elliptic curve. Digital signature, one-way hashing, zero-knowledge proof, certificate and certificate authority. Secure information infrastructure, virtual private network (VPN), online shopping and payment systems, e-cash. Economic impact. Smart card, steganography, time stamping. Cryptanalysis technology. Authentication protocols, analysis and evaluation.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have the knowledge about computer/system/network security; cryptography; digital copyright/e-commerce, e-cash, payment systems, and digital forensics.
required_readings: Computer Security: Principles and Practice (3rd Edition) by William Stallings and Lawrie Brown, Publisher: Prentice Hall, 2014. Counter Hack Reloaded: A Step-by-step Guide to Computer Attacks and Effective Defenses (2nd Edition) by Ed Skoudis and Tom Liston. Publisher: Prentice Hall, 2005. Introduction to Computer Securityby Michael Goodrich and Roberto Tamassia, Published by Pearson Higher Education, 2011. Understanding Cryptography: A Textbook for Students and Practionersby Christof Paar and Jan Pelzl, Published by Springer, 2010 The Web Application Hacker's Handbook - Discovering and Exploiting Security Flaws, 2nd Editionby Dafydd Stuttard and Marcus Pinto, Published by Wiley, 2011.  Charlie Kaufman, Radia Perlman, Mike Spenciner, Network Security, 2nd Editionby Dafydd Stuttard and Marcus Pinto, Published by Prentice Hall, 2002.
recommended_readings: Ross Anderson, "Security Engineering, 2nd Edition" Wiley, 2008 Cryptography Decrypted by H.X.Mel and Doris M.Baker. Publisher: Addison Wesley, 2000. Alfred J. Menezes, Paul C. Van Oorschot, Scott A. Vanstone, "Handbook of Applied Cryptography", CRC Press, 1996. A precise, mathematicaloriented reference. Bruce Schneier, Applied Cryptography, 2nd Edition, Wiley, 1996 Stephen Northcutt et al, Inside Network Security Perimeter, 2nd Edition, New Riders, 2005 Stuart McClure, Joel Scambray and George Kurtz, Hacking Exposed, 6th Edition, McGrawHill Osborne, 2009 Simon Garfinkel, Gene Spafford, Web Security, Privacy and Commerce, 2nd Edition O'Reilly, 2002. John Viega and Gary McGraw, Building Secure Software, Addison Wesley, 2002. William R. Cheswick, Steven M. Bellovin and Aviel D. Rubin, Firewalls and Internet Security, 2nd Edition, Addison Wesley, 2003. Allan Liska, The Practice of Network Security, Prentice Hall, 2003 Lincoln D. Stein, Web Security, Addison Wesley, 1998 Aviel D. Rubin, White-Hat Security Arsenal, Addison Wesley, 2001 William Stallings, Cryptography and Network Security, 5th Edition, Prentice Hall, 2011 Steve Burnett and Stephen Paine, RSA Security's Official Guide to Cryptography, RSA Press, 2001 Roger A. Grimes, Malicious Mobile Code, 2001, O'Reilly Press Anonymous, Maximum Security, 4th Edition, SAMS, 2003.  Charles P. Pfleeger and Shari Lawrence Pfleeger, Security in Computing, 4th Edition, Prentice Hall, 2006 Mark O'Neill, et al., Web Services Security, Wiley, 2003. Donald E. Eastlake III and Kitty Niles, Security XML, Addison Wesley, 2003 Kevin D. Mitnick and William L. Simon, The Art of Deception, Wiley, 2002. Niels Ferguson and Bruce Schneier, Practical Cryptography, Wiley, 2003 Bruce Schneier, Secrets and Lies - Digital Security in a Networked World, Wiley, 2004 Warwick Ford and Michael S. Baum, Secure Electronic Commerce, 2nd Edition, Prentice Hall, 2001 Cyrus Peikari and Seth Fogie, Wireless Maximum Security, SAMS, 2003 Mario Heiderich et al, Web Application Obfuscation, Syngress press, 2011 Justin Clarke, SQL Injection - Attacks and Defense, Syngress press, 2009 Sean Smith and John Marchesini, The Craft of System Security, Addison Wesley, 2007. Eric Rescoria, SSL and TLS, Addison Wesley, 2001. Scott Barman, Writing Information Security Policies, New Riders, 2001.

title: E-Commerce Data Mining Techniques
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Data mining provides techniques for the analysis, understanding and extraction of useful information from huge databases. These techniques are used in business, finance, medicine and engineering. This course will introduce the techniques used in data mining for E-Commerce information. Topics will include clustering, classifi cation, estimation,forecasting, statistical analysis and visualization tools.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should understand the foundation in data mining concepts and techniques, and acquire the knowledge of E-commerce data mining applications.
required_readings: “Data Mining - Concepts and Techniques”, J. Han, M. Kamber, and J. Pei (Morgan Kaufmann) “Data Science for Business”, F. Provost and T. Fawcett, O’Reilly “Data Mining Using SAS Enterprise Miner”, R. Matignon (Wiley)

title: Distributed and Mobile Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Distributed and mobile systems are the key framework for E-Commerce applications. This course covers the principles of distributed systems (including mobile applications) and software, and the engineering mechanisms for their specifi cation, design, deployment, and evaluation. Topics include: architectural models for distributed systems, server techniques, remote procedure call and multicast communications, RFID technology, emerging standards and platforms, distributed transactions, concurrency control, reliability and security issues.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have learned the problems that occur during construction of distributed systems; the principles and techniques to solve them; the infrastructure and components for distributed and mobile systems; and the practical applications of distributed systems, particularly in e-commerce technologies.
required_readings: Distributed Systems: Concepts and Design, George Coulouris, Jean Dollimore, and Tim Kindberg, Addison-Wesley, 5th edition, 2012.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

title: Network and Web Programming
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: This course addresses the techniques for programming in both low-level (network) and high-level (web) of the Internet. Network programmes include: client-server system design; interprocess communication; sockets; blocking and nonblocking I/O; multithreaded process; iterative and concurrent server designs; web programming includes: HTML, JAVA, Web page design and construction.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should understand and develop distributed applications using selected network and web programming technologies.
required_readings: Y. Daniel Liang, Introduction to Java Programming, 8th Edition, Pearson
recommended_readings: Danny Goodman, Dynamic HTML: the definitive reference, O’Reilly, 2002 Dick Oliver & Michael Morrison, Sams teach yourself HTML and CSS in 24 hours, Sams, 2006 Shelley Powers, Learning Javascript, O’Reilly, 2007 Luke Welling and Laura Thomson, PHP and MySQL web development, Addison-Wesley, 2009

title: Open Systems for E-Commerce
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Introduction to open system standards and protocols. Transaction protocols. Electronic commerce applications using open system and artificial intelligence technologies. Application of intelligent agents for automated transaction processing. Integration of web programming techniques with information and communication systems. Case studies for E-Commerce open system applications.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have knowledge about the backbone technologies of E-Commerce.
required_readings: Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet (5th edition) by James F. Kurose and Keith W. Ross, Addison Wesley, 2009. Introduction to Data Mining, by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach, and Vipin Kumar, Addison Wesley, 2005. Community Detection and Mining in Social Media, by Lei Tang and Huan Liu, Morgan & Claypool Publisher, 2010.

title: Project I in E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: An individual or a team project on E-Commerce technologies.
outcome: After completing a project, a student might have involved in the following (not restricted): Design of a system related to E-commerce, development, test and evaluation; Development and/or application of a theory or model to understand or analyze a system or a process; Case study of a real application or process; and/or Simulation of a system or process based on an analytical or computational model.
required_readings: Robert T. Clemen, Making Hard Decisions: An Introduction to Decision Analysis, Duxbury Press, 1996. A, Shtub, J.F. Bard, and S. Globerson, Project Management: Engineering, Technology, and Implementation, Prentice Hall, 1994. Chopra and Meindl, Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning and Operation, Pearson, 2013. Jiawei Han and Micheline Kamber, Morgan Kaufmann: Data Mining – Concepts and Techniques (2nd Edition), 2006. Avi Silberschatz, Henry F. Korth, and S. Sudarshan, McGraw-Hill: Database System Concepts (5th Edition), 2010

instructors:
Dr. PAN Hong, 
Professor SO Man Cho

title: Information Technology Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: The challenges, techniques and technologies associated with the management of information technology (IT) for logistics and supply chain operations. The linkage of IT to business models and corporate strategies in logistics and supply chain industry. Information systems and technology planning, sourcing and acquisition, budgeting and deployment. Performance evaluation and audit. Standard, privacy and security policies.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should understand the important facets of managing information technology which emphasizes the strategic perspectives of information system management and the importance of matching business models with the new technologies in E-commerce.
required_readings: Efraim Turban, Linda Volonio, “Information Technology for Management: Transforming Organizations in the Digital Economy”, 7th Edition, Wiley.

instructors:
Dr. YIU Siu Wai, 
Professor WONG Kam Fai William

title: Decision Methodologies with Financial Applications
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Utility functions and mean-variance theory. Probability models and price dynamics of securities. Financial analysis models including: Geometric Brownian motion, Ito’s lemma, Black-Scholes model. Capital asset pricing. Models of risks. Risk hedging. Optimization techniques for investment and portfolio management.
outcome: After completing the course, students are expected to understand basic decision methodologies and their applications in finance.
required_readings: D. G. Luenberger, Investment Science, 2nd edition, Oxford University Press, 2013

title: Engineering Economics
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Principles of engineering economy. Value and cost, cash flows. Economic analysis of alternatives, technological, social and human factors. Models involving allocation and scheduling of resources. Analytical techniques for evaluating industrial projects. Relationship between economics of technical choice and industrial productivity. Basic financial accounting concepts, financial statements.
outcome: At the conclusion of this course, students were able to understand basic cost concepts, terminology, and methods to estimate and optimize cost of design projects; understand time value of money and apply this knowledge through various methods to evaluate alternative projects; and learn the techniques to account for depreciation, tax, and inflation in the evaluation of engineering projects.
required_readings: Engineering Economy, William G. Sullivan; Elin M. Wicks; C. Patrick Koelling

title: Supply Chain Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Management of moving raw materials, in-process inventory and finished-goods; transferring information and payment. Topics include: electronic information and payment transfer and its impact, distribution, forecasting, inventory management, purchasing and supplier management, ERP systems supply chain integration and strategic partnering. Impacts of E-Commerce in supply chain management.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have learned the SCM vocabulary; understood major qualitative features regarding the operations of a supply chain and learned some basic SCM analytical tools and gained insights into the IT implications.
required_readings: Chopra and Meindl, Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning and Operation, 5th edition, 2013, Pearson
recommended_readings: Heizer and Render, Operations Management: Sustainability and Supply Chain Management, 11th edition, 2014, Pearson Nahmias, Production and Operations Analysis, 6th Edition, 2008, Irwin/McGraw-Hill

title: Project II in E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: An individual or a team project on E-Commerce technologies.
outcome: After completing a project, a student might have involved in the following (not restricted): Design of a system related to E-commerce, development, test and evaluation; Development and/or application of a theory or model to understand or analyze a system or a process; Case study of a real application or process; and/or Simulation of a system or process based on an analytical or computational model.
